Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2014 08:53PM Renee51 wrote: Claire- 2014, I know this is hard to do, but try to get your mind on something else. I am speaking from experience as I just received diagnosis a couple of weeks ago. I am "waiting" to go to surgery a week from today. I can honestly say, the waiting is horrible, but keep yourself busy and when those intrusive thoughts come, don't dwell there, read a book, surf the web, go for a run, just do something, stay active. Just some advice that worked for me.
Posts.Title: Waiting for Biopsy Results claire-2014 Holeinone

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2014 02:29PM Renee51 wrote: I had steriotactic breast biopsy this morning. I want to let those of you who are waiting to have yours, while it is never pleasant to have a biopsy, it wasn't bad at all. the most painfully time was the xylecaine to numb the skin, after that a somewhat strange sensation when the biopsy was taken, it did not hurt, just a little weird. Hang in there....  BTW, I am expecting my results on friday.

Posts.Title: radiation recall.. or whatever this is? mfml cakes

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2014 12:03AM Renee51 wrote: When I was called for a second spot compression mammogram because I have micro calcifications, I decided to be "proactive." It took 2 weeks for me to get a letter saying they wanted "more info" and second mammogram. My second mammogram was scheduled for a thursday. I went the same day they called to give me an appt. and ask to be worked in that day. I was done with additional scans an hour later. That was on a monday. The following wednesday afternoon, I went to medical records and requested a copy of the report. I knew immediately I needed a biopsy according to the "impression" report. By the time, I got home, my PCP was calling to tell me what I already knew. Be proactive. Knowledge is power! Go to the hospital, pick up your report and call your doctor for answers.
Posts.Title: Scared out of my mind!!!! Mompv Mompv

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2014 05:10AM Renee51 wrote: wandawoman, that is exactly what I am afraid of. I know I am lucky that mammogram identified the cancer so early. I am not afraid of what I know is there, it is the things we don't know about that is frightening. BTW, plastic surgeon isn't available on 25th, so now date is changed to the 29th. I had a truly bad day yesterday. I don't want to be angry and bitter, because I am thankful, but let's just say as all the surgeons and oncologist offices were calling, scheduling, setting apps for sentinode mapping, etc. reality slapped me in the face.
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2014 06:13PM Renee51 wrote: I chose bilateral mastectomy because I have had several "issues" with my left breast, never the right. However, on screening mammogram, low and behold I had cancer. I figured with all the lumps and cysts I had had on the left, I didn't want to live with the constant fear of waiting for the next problem. I don't regret my decision.

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2014 04:13AM Renee51 wrote: I got a call today from my PCP that after my second mammogram was completed that  I need a breast biopsy. My report says it is considered "BI RADS 4b- suspicious abnormality with intermediate level of concern." I understand what BI RADS 4 means, but my question is what does the "b" stand for?  I am so thankful that I have found this site. I am sitting up tonight alone and unable to sleep. I will deal with whatever comes my way. I have a great support system in family and friends and I know I am so blessed. But, I must admit I am scared.

Posts.Title: Biopsy results: benign vs pre-cancerous Lina999 awb

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2014 04:34AM Renee51 wrote: I live in a rather small community and know the surgeon and the nurse. That probably has much to do with getting results. My surgeon told me to call within two days and results might be back and they would let me know them. I told the nurse and so they decided not to give me a follow up visit with him. Then I got a call and they still want me to come in to see him after all. She said, in case something comes back that is "concerning," they don't want anything to "fall through the cracks."
Posts.Title: Biopsy results: benign vs pre-cancerous Lina999 awb

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2014 04:38AM Renee51 wrote: mjm1, I have thought the same thing. What if they can't locate it and want me to just wait? I don't think that will be an option for me. However, if they can't locate the area with needle, they also wouldn't be able to "mark" it for the surgeon either. Praying that radiologist can get to the area and biopsy it!
Posts.Title: Biopsy results: benign vs pre-cancerous Lina999 awb

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2014 08:10AM Renee51 wrote: Infobabe, I feel the same way. They inserted the marker so if the biopsy indicates cancer, then surgeon knows exactly where the cancer is. If it's not cancer, well then, I will have mammogram every six mouths for about a year and half. The marker will pinpoint the area of concern. They explained that sometimes all the calcifications are removed during biopsy and they can have difficulty locating the specific location and this "marks the spot." you can't feel it, it was only about 1mm in size. (they showed it to me before insertion) and It doesn't hurt, can't even tell it is there now. I say do everything you can to make it easier for those to treat you to be able to do their job to the best of their abilities. This titanium marker allows them to do this without second guessing themselves.

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2014 10:08PM Renee51 wrote: Thank you all for sharing. I am going tomorrow to meet with the plastic surgeon and on friday I meet with the oncologist. Call me conflicted.  I want to make good decisions and you all are helping me so very much. I am forever grateful!!
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2014 11:45AM Renee51 wrote: I saw the surgeon this past friday. Scheduled for steriotactic biopsy a week from today. Everything seems to take a week to 10 days. However, the nurse at the surgeons office gave me a number directly to her phone that I can call friday for results. So thankful for her! Also thankful that surgeon says if biopsy comes by that it is cancer, we have every reason to believe it was caught very early and would not likely be invasive. That in itself is a relief. I am less worried now. The wait is exhausting.
Posts.Title: Biopsy results: benign vs pre-cancerous Lina999 awb

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2014 09:18PM Renee51 wrote: I am an RN also. I have been a nurse for 30 years. I just completed my masters as a FNP 5 weeks ago, only to find out I had an "area of concern" on the mammogram. I was just diagnosed four days ago with DCIS.  I am considering a double mastectomy. I don't want to have radiation therapy and am hoping to avoid that. I also don't want to worry every time I have to go to the doctor, or have a mammogram, etc. I am fortunate that as a nursing instructor I have the summer off. I will have to take the last 3 weeks of school off though. Can you guys elaborate on why you chose mastectomy or lumpectomy? Thanks so much. It is encouraging to hear from all of my fellow nurses who have undergone treatment and who have not only survived, but are thriving!  Thank you for sharing.
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2014 11:13AM Renee51 wrote: I saw my oncologist for the first time yesterday. She explained every single detail of the reports. She reassured me that I was making good choices, and that given the same scenario she would choose the same path I have decided on. That has made me feel so much better. I have second guessed every single move I make and now I feel a little more settled and at peace with decisions.
